metadata.titleEn: In situ boron isotopic data of tourmaline from Neogene magmatic rocks in the northern and southern margin of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau
metadata.description: The data set includes tourmaline in-situ boron isotope data and major element data of the Neogene magmatic rocks in the northern and southern margin of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau. The major element data of tourmaline were obtained by electron probe analysis, and the in-situ boron isotope data of tourmaline were obtained by laser ablation multi receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. Tourmaline is derived from two Pliocene mica rhyolites from hudongliang in Songpan Ganzi massif and two Miocene mica granites from cuonadong in Himalayan massif δ The 11b values were -10.47 ± 0.54‰。 And -12.48 ± 1.04‰。 We believe that these strongly peraluminous magmatic rocks from the northern and southern margins of Tibet were mainly formed by subduction or partial melting of overlying continental sedimentary rocks.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file. The file name "data. Xlsx" represents the in-situ boron isotope data and major element data of tourmaline.

authorList.unitEn: Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences

literatureList.titleEn: In situ boron isotopic analyses of tourmalines from Neogene magmatic rocks in the northern and southern margins of Tibet: Evidence for melting of continental crust and sediment recycling
literatureList.referenceEn: Gou, G.-N., Wang, Q., Wyman, D. A., Xia, X.-P., Wei, G.-J., & Guo, H.-F. (2017). In situ boron isotopic analyses of tourmalines from Neogene magmatic rocks in the northern and southern margins of Tibet: Evidence for melting of continental crust and sediment recycling. Solid Earth Sciences, 2(2), 43-54.

Verification.Question: Does the use of laser ablation-multi collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-MC-ICP-MS) provide accurate in-situ boron isotope data for tourmaline in Neogene igneous rocks?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used for obtaining in-situ boron isotope data and major element data from magmatic rocks?
Concept Completion.Answer: Electron probe analysis, laser ablation-multicollector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to obtain in situ boron isotope data in Neogene magmatic rocks from the northern and southern margins of the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to obtain in situ boron isotope data in Neogene magmatic rocks involves the use of laser ablation-multicollector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-MC-ICP-MS) to analyze tourmaline samples from micaceous rhyolites and micaceous granites.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific attributes of in-situ boron isotope data in tourmaline from Neogene magmatic rocks in the northern and southern margins of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?

Quantification.Question: What is the range of δ11B values observed in the boron isotope dataset of tourmaline from Neogene magmatic rocks at the northern and southern margins of the Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What does 'in-situ boron isotope data' mean in the context of Neogene igneous rocks from the northern and southern margins of the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: In the context of Neogene igneous rocks from the northern and southern margins of the Tibetan Plateau, 'in-situ boron isotope data' refers to the boron isotope measurements obtained directly from samples of tourmaline (a boron-bearing mineral) within these rocks. These measurements are conducted using laser ablation-multicollector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-MC-ICP-MS), which allows for precise isotopic analysis of boron within the mineral structure, providing insights into the geochemical processes involved in the formation of these rocks.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the selection of specific analytical techniques, such as electronic probe analysis and laser ablation multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, in the data collection of boron isotopes and major elements in igneous rocks?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The selection of electronic probe analysis for major elements and laser ablation multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for in situ boron isotopes is likely influenced by the need for precise and accurate measurements of the elemental and isotopic composition of tourmaline in the Neogene igneous rocks from the north and south margins of the Tibetan Plateau. These methods provide the resolution and sensitivity required to analyze the complex geological samples, which are considered to have resulted from processes like subduction or partial melting of overlying continental sedimentary rocks.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are typically followed to collect and analyze in-situ boron isotope data and major element data from tourmaline in Neogene magmatic rocks of the northern and southern edges of the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The in-situ boron isotope data from tourmaline are collected using laser ablation-multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, while the major element data are obtained through electron probe microanalysis. These techniques are applied to tourmaline from Miocene biotite granites and Pliocene biotite-rhyolites to understand the formation processes of strongly peraluminous magmatic rocks due to subduction or partial melting of overlying continental sedimentary rocks.
